events.originalText: A shooting at a branch of the Israeli LGBT organization the Aguda in Tel Aviv resulted in two deaths.
events.subtitle: Tel Aviv gay centre shooting
events.headline: Shooting at Israeli LGBT organization in Tel Aviv leaves two dead

events.originalText: Bridge 9340, carrying Interstate 35W across the Mississippi River in Minneapolis, Minnesota, suffered a catastrophic failure and collapsed, killing 13 people and injuring 145 others.
events.subtitle: I-35W Mississippi River bridge
events.headline: Interstate 35W bridge in Minneapolis collapses, killing 13

events.originalText: Nearly 400 people died in a supermarket fire in Asunción, Paraguay, when exits were locked to prevent people from stealing merchandise.
events.subtitle: Ycuá Bolaños supermarket fire
events.headline: Nearly 400 dead in Paraguay supermarket fire due to locked exits

events.originalText: U.S. president George H. W. Bush delivered a speech in the Ukrainian parliament in Kiev warning against independence from the Soviet Union.
events.subtitle: George H. W. Bush
events.headline: George H. W. Bush warns against Ukrainian independence in Kiev speech

events.originalText: Commercial peat cutters discovered a preserved bog body, now known as Lindow Man (head pictured), at Lindow Moss in Cheshire, England.
events.subtitle: Peat
events.headline: Preserved bog body discovered in Cheshire, England

events.originalText: "Video Killed the Radio Star" by the Buggles became the first music video broadcast on the American cable television network MTV.
events.subtitle: Video Killed the Radio Star
events.headline: Buggles' 'Video Killed the Radio Star' first music video on MTV

events.originalText: The Concert for Bangladesh, a pair of benefit concerts organised by George Harrison and Ravi Shankar for refugees of the Bangladesh genocide, took place at Madison Square Garden in New York.
events.subtitle: The Concert for Bangladesh
events.headline: Concert for Bangladesh held at Madison Square Garden in New York

events.originalText: Several days of anti-Jewish rioting began in Bratislava, instigated by former Slovak partisans opposed to the restitution of Jewish property after the Holocaust in Slovakia.
events.subtitle: Partisan Congress riots
events.headline: Anti-Jewish rioting begins in Bratislava after Holocaust in Slovakia

events.originalText: Harriet Quimby became the first woman to earn an Aero Club of America aviator certificate.
events.subtitle: Harriet Quimby
events.headline: Harriet Quimby first woman to earn Aero Club of America aviator certificate

events.originalText: Belgian carillonneur Jef Denyn hosted the world's first carillon concert at St. Rumbold's Cathedral in Mechelen.
events.subtitle: Jef Denyn
events.headline: World's first carillon concert hosted at St. Rumbold's Cathedral in Mechelen

events.originalText: Colorado is admitted as the 38th U.S. state.
events.subtitle: Colorado
events.headline: Colorado admitted as 38th U.S. state

events.originalText: Three days of rioting erupted after a parade in Philadelphia, celebrating the end of slavery in the West Indies, was attacked by a mob.
events.subtitle: Lombard Street riot
events.headline: Rioting erupts in Philadelphia after attack on slavery parade

events.originalText: Britain celebrated a Grand Jubilee to mark 100 years since the accession of George I and 16 years since the start of the Battle of the Nile.
events.subtitle: Grand Jubilee of 1814
events.headline: Britain celebrates Grand Jubilee marking 100 years since George I's accession

events.originalText: First Barbary War: USS Enterprise, an American schooner, captured the Tripolitan polacca Tripoli in a single-ship action off the coast of Libya.
events.subtitle: First Barbary War
events.headline: USS Enterprise captures Tripolitan polacca Tripoli in First Barbary War

events.originalText: French Revolutionary Wars: The Battle of the Nile, between a British fleet commanded by Horatio Nelson and a French fleet under François-Paul Brueys d'Aigalliers, began at Aboukir Bay off the Egyptian coast.
events.subtitle: French Revolutionary Wars
events.headline: Battle of the Nile begins off Egyptian coast between British and French fleets

events.originalText: British scientist Joseph Priestley (pictured) liberated oxygen gas, corroborating the discovery of the element by German-Swedish chemist Carl Wilhelm Scheele.
events.subtitle: Joseph Priestley
events.headline: Joseph Priestley liberates oxygen gas, confirming discovery by Carl Wilhelm Scheele

events.originalText: George Louis, Elector of Hanover, became King George I of Great Britain, marking the beginning of the Georgian era.
events.subtitle: Electorate of Hanover
events.headline: George Louis becomes King George I of Great Britain, starting Georgian era

events.originalText: Arab–Byzantine wars: Led by Ibrahim II of Ifriqiya, Aghlabid forces captured the Byzantine stronghold of Taormina, concluding the Muslim conquest of Sicily.
events.subtitle: Arab–Byzantine wars
events.headline: Aghlabid forces capture Byzantine stronghold of Taormina in Arab-Byzantine wars

events.originalText: Upon the death of Justin I, his nephew and adopted son Justinian I became the sole ruler of the Byzantine Empire.
events.subtitle: Justin I
events.headline: Justinian I becomes sole ruler of Byzantine Empire after Justin I's death

events.originalText: War of Actium: Octavian defeated the forces of Mark Antony and Cleopatra at Alexandria, establishing Roman Egypt.
events.subtitle: War of Actium
events.headline: Octavian defeats Mark Antony and Cleopatra at Alexandria in War of Actium
